I married the first person I dated, which either means I am extremely lucky or extremely successful at dating

1326904060902072322 [2020-11-12] @visakanv 💜 30
"what else have you been lucky with?"

1. employment. I only ever had 1 serious job, and it was with a great boss who I admire, who sought me out bc he liked my blog. made good $$, learned a ton, he was like a therapist-coach who paid *me*, great relationships with ex-colleagues
↓
1326904615628050442 [2020-11-12] @visakanv 💜 25
2. twitter. how tf do I have 25,000 twitter followers from around the world? I'm just some random nerd from singapore. I don't have any qualifications. I never went to college. where I am is a function of the merit of my thoughts, my A+ reply game, & my sensitivity to opportunity
↓
1326905325782446083 [2020-11-12] @visakanv 💜 23 🔁 2
3. investments. I don't invest much, but when I buy things, they go up in value. so far i've bought tesla, shopify (on day 1), amazon, bitcoin (a bunch of years ago). it's not *retirement* money, but it's certainly "hmm I don't need a job anytime soon that's nice" money
↓
1326905786195382275 [2020-11-12] @visakanv 💜 23
there are things I suck terribly at. I suck at handling calendars, schedules, "balancing the books" type budgeting. I suck at remembering things. I have a chaotic ADHD mind that refuses to do anything I put down on a todo list. but I've designed my life *around* these things
↓
1326907047292628992 [2020-11-12] @visakanv 💜 44 🔁 3
I've basically always had this approach: problems are solvable. practice solving problems and you'll get better at them. if you can't solve the big problems you can break them down into littler problems and solve those, or solve the ones *around* it

https://t.co/O6od1IWkr2
  [Quoting @GeniesLoki: 1. Instead of having a profound spiritual awakening you can just actually solve your problems.]
↓
1326907655672254471 [2020-11-12] @visakanv 💜 39 🔁 1 [(SEED) type=semantic_search]
when you do this long enough, well enough, you start to discover something strange: not everyone wants to solve their problems. 😂 lots of people don't believe problems are solvable. or they're afraid of what happens after they solve their problem. many tiers and layers to this

Images:
  - [Image #0] The image is a screenshot of a webpage titled "The XY Problem." The title is displayed prominently at the top, followed by a section labeled "See Also: Asking Smart Questions."
    
    Below this, the page is divided into two main sections: "What is it?" and "What to do about it?"
    
    **What is it?**
    
    This section explains the concept of the XY problem, which occurs when someone asks for help with their attempted solution (Y) rather than their actual problem (X). The result is wasted time and energy for both the person seeking help and those providing it. The section outlines the characteristics of the XY problem, including:
    
    * The user wants to achieve X but doesn't know how.
    * The user thinks they can solve X if they can just figure out Y.
    * The user doesn't know how to do Y either.
    * The user asks for help with Y.
    * Others try to assist with Y, but are confused because it seems like a strange problem.
    * After much interaction and wasted time, it becomes clear that the user really wants help with X, and that Y wasn't even a suitable solution for X.
    
    The problem arises when people get stuck on what they believe is the solution and are unable to step back and explain the issue in full.
    
    **What to do about it?**
    
    This section provides guidance on how to address the XY problem. It suggests:
    
    1. Always including information about the broader picture along with any attempted solution.
    2. Providing details if someone asks for more information.
    3. Sharing why you've ruled out other solutions if there are any.
    
    The section concludes with a reminder that if your diagnostic theories were accurate, you wouldn't be asking for help.

rating.reasoning_summary: This strand centers on David MacIver's 2022 tweet: 'A lot of visible problems that you can't seem to solve are secretly solutions you don't want to admit to adopting to problems you don't want to admit to having.' The boundary object is psychological defense mechanisms masquerading as unsolvable problems. The arc spans 2011-2025, evolving from Visa's early observations about identity-as-pain (Tolle quote) through DRMacIver's crystallization of the concept, to widespread adoption as a diagnostic tool for stuck patterns. This is primarily constructive—the community builds shared vocabulary ('incompetence as competence,' 'maladjustment as political act') and applies the frame across domains (relationships, creativity, addiction, social media use). High cohesion around rationalist/postrat networks. The evolution is medium-to-high: the core insight remains stable, but applications deepen (Rival's hyperrationality-as-defense, Malcolm's coherence therapy integration, Yatharth's somatic dimension). Utility is high for therapeutic/coaching contexts but requires significant sophistication to deploy without causing defensiveness.

essential_tweets.annotation: Pre-history: Visa's 2011 Tolle quote establishing 'identity from pain' as a core problem pattern
Visa's 2020 observation that 'not everyone wants to solve their problems'—the seed of the insight
DRMacIver's July 2021 formulation: 'People are committed to believing they can't solve their problems when they're choosing not to'
The Artifact (Dec 2022): DRMacIver's canonical tweet—the boundary object for the entire strand
Visa's endorsement ('one of the best tweets ever written') gives it memetic momentum
Application: Visa uses it to diagnose therapy resistance—'issues are resolutions to other issues they don't want to face'
Integration with creativity/chaos theory: 'The problem is misframed because they don't want to face the actual problem'
Expansion: 'Incompetence as secret competence'—the frame applied to self-sabotage patterns
Pairing with Rival's 'hyperrationality as childhood defense' tweet—adding developmental depth
Outcome: Rival reports breakthrough productivity after 5 years of 'taking the problem seriously'—proof of concept
